nodes.name: Every agent has thriving as a goal
nodes.fol: (forall (a) (if (agent a) (exists (e)(and (goal e a)(thrive' e a)))))
nodes.english: It is formally convenient to assume that agents have one plan that they are always developing, executing, monitoring, and revising, and that that plan is in the service of a single goal called 'Thriving'

nodes.name: Type constraint for thrive
nodes.fol: (forall (e a) (if (thrive' e a)(agent a)))
nodes.english: If e is an eventuality of a thriving, then a is an agent

nodes.name: Type constraint for pleasure
nodes.fol: (forall (e p) (if (pleasure e p)(person p)))
nodes.english: The expression (pleasure e p) means that the eventuality e is the experience of person p feeling pleasure

nodes.name: Pleasure is self-evident - knowledge
nodes.fol: (forall (e0 e p) (if (and (pleasure' e0 e p)(Rexists e0))(know p e0)))
nodes.english: When someone feels pleasure, they know it, and that fact is in their focus of attention

nodes.name: Pleasure is in focus
nodes.fol: (forall (e p) (if (pleasure e p)(inFocus e p)))
nodes.english: When someone feels pleasure, that fact is in their focus of attention

nodes.name: Believing in pleasure implies reality
nodes.fol: (forall (e0 e p) (if (and (pleasure' e0 e p)(believe p e0)) (Rexist e0)))
nodes.english: Moreover, if someone believes he or she feels pleasure, they really do. It is not something one can be mistaken about

nodes.name: Pleasure is private experience
nodes.fol: (forall (p1 p2 e1 e2) (if (and (pleasure e1 p1)(pleasure e2 p2)(nequal p1 p2)) (nequal e1 e2)))
nodes.english: Pleasure is a private experience. If two distinct persons p1 and p2 have experiences of pleasure e1 and e2, the experiences are distinct

nodes.name: Definition of pleasurable
nodes.fol: (forall (e1 a) (iff (pleasurable e1 p) (exists (e) (and (pleasure e p)(cause e1 e)))))
nodes.english: A closely related concept identifies the cause of the pleasure. Eventuality e1 is pleasurable to person p if e1 causes the experience e of pleasure in p

nodes.name: Knowing causes of pleasure
nodes.fol: (forall (e0 e1 p) (if (and (pleasurable' e0 e1 p)(Rexists e0)(etc)) (know p e0)))
nodes.english: We normally know the causes of our feelings of pleasure, but not always

nodes.name: Pleasurable things become goals
nodes.fol: (forall (e0 e1 e2 p) (if (and (pleasurable' e0 e1 p)(believe' e2 p e0)(etc)) (exists (g0) (and (goal' g0 e1 p)(cause e2 g0)))))
nodes.english: The principal property of pleasure, for our purposes, is that if we believe something is pleasurable, it will often cause us to adopt it as a goal

nodes.name: Pleasure causes belief in thriving
nodes.fol: (forall (e p) (if (and (pleasure e p)(etc)) (exists (e1 e2) (and (thrive' e1 p)(believe' e2 p e1)(cause e e2)))))
nodes.english: When we feel pleasure, that normally causes us to believe we are thriving

nodes.name: Value correlates with pleasure
nodes.fol: (forall (e1 e2 p) (if (and (moreValuable e1 e2 p)(etc)) (morePleasurable e1 e2 p)))
nodes.english: Defeasibly, the more valuable a goal is to us, the more pleasurable its achievement should be

nodes.name: Type constraint for pain
nodes.fol: (forall (e p) (if (pain e p)(person p)))
nodes.english: The expression (pain e p) means that the eventuality e is the experience of person p feeling pain

nodes.name: Pain is self-evident - knowledge
nodes.fol: (forall (e0 e p) (if (and (pain' e0 e p)(Rexists e0))(know p e0)))
nodes.english: When someone feels pain, they know it, and that fact is in their focus of attention. It is not something they can be mistaken about

nodes.name: Pain is in focus
nodes.fol: (forall (e p) (if (pain e p)(inFocus e p)))
nodes.english: When someone feels pain, that fact is in their focus of attention. In these axioms the pain itself (e) is in focus

nodes.name: Pain is private experience
nodes.fol: (forall (p1 p2 e1 e2) (if (and (pain e1 p1)(pain e2 p2)(nequal p1 p2)) (nequal e1 e2)))
nodes.english: Pain is a private experience. If two distinct persons p1 and p2 have experiences of pain e1 and e2, the experiences are distinct

nodes.name: Definition of painful
nodes.fol: (forall (e1 a) (iff (painful e1 p) (exists (e) (and (pain e p)(cause e1 e)))))
nodes.english: A closely related concept identifies the cause of the pain. Eventuality e1 is painful to person p if e1 causes the experience e of pain in p

nodes.name: Knowing causes of pain
nodes.fol: (forall (e p) (if (and (painful' e0 e1 p)(Rexists e0)(etc)) (know p e0)))
nodes.english: We normally know the causes of our feelings of pain, but not always

nodes.name: Pain indicates body damage
nodes.fol: (forall (e p) (if (and (pain e p)(etc)) (exists (x e1 e2) (and (bodyPart x p)(changeFrom' e1 e2)(intact' e2 x) (cause e1 e)))))
nodes.english: More than pleasure, pain tends to be associated with a particular body part and indicates that damage is being done to that body part. Breaking your arm is painful, and the pain is telling you that your arm is broken

nodes.name: Painful things cause goals to stop pain
nodes.fol: (forall (e0 e1 e2 p) (if (and (painful' e0 e1 p)(believe' e2 p e0)(etc)) (exists (g0 e3) (and (goal' g0 e3 p)(not' e3 e1)(cause e2 g0)))))
nodes.english: The principal property of pain, for our purposes, is that if we believe something is painful, it will often cause us to adopt as a goal causing the pain to stop

nodes.name: Pain causes belief in not thriving
nodes.fol: (forall (e p) (if (and (pain e p)(etc)) (exists (e1 e2 e3) (and (thrive' e1 p)(not' e3 e1)(believe' e2 p e3) (cause e e2)))))
nodes.english: When we feel pain, that normally causes us to believe we are not thriving

nodes.name: Cost correlates with pain
nodes.fol: (forall (x y p) (if (and (moreCostly e1 e2 p)(etc)) (morePainful e1 e2 p)))
nodes.english: Just as we did with pleasure, we can help out Martians and robots by saying that there is a correlation between how painful something is and the cost of the goals we are willing to sacrifice to eliminate the pain

nodes.name: Definition of stvslt (short-term vs long-term)
nodes.fol: (forall (a e1 t1 e2 t2) (if (stvslt a e1 t1 e2 t2) (exists (e3 e4) (and (agent a)(before t1 t2) (atTime' e3 e1 t1)(goal e3 a) (atTime' e4 e2 t2)(goal e4 a) (conflictingGoals e3 e4 a) (moreValuable e2 e1 a)))))
nodes.english: A very common conflict when we are trying to decide what to do is between satisfying short-term goals and pursuing long-term goals. The constraints are: one time is before the other, the goals conflict, and the long-term goal is more valuable

nodes.name: Definition of pickST (pick short-term)
nodes.fol: (forall (e a e1) (iff (pickST' e a e1) (exists (t1 e2 t2 e4 g2 e5) (and (stvslt a e1 t1 e2 t2) (atTime' e4 e2 t2)(goal' g2 e4 a) (changeFrom' e5 g2)(gen e5 e)))))
nodes.english: To pick the short-term goal e1 is to be in this situation and to change from having e2 as a goal. Picking the short-term option is equivalent to abandoning e4 as a goal

nodes.name: Definition of pickLT (pick long-term)
nodes.fol: (forall (e a e2) (iff (pickLT' e a e2) (exists (e1 t1 t2 e3 g1 e5) (and (stvslt a e1 t1 e2 t2) (atTime' e3 e1 t1)(goal' g1 e3 a) (changeFrom' e5 g1)(gen e5 e)))))
nodes.english: The definition of picking the long-term option e2 is similar - changing from having the short-term goal

nodes.name: Definition of gratificationDelay
nodes.fol: (forall (t e1 e2 a) (iff (gratificationDelay t e1 e2 a) (exists (t1 t2) (and (stvslt a e1 t1 e2 t2) (intervalBetween t t1 t2)))))
nodes.english: We can call the interval between t1 and t2 the 'gratification delay'

nodes.name: Gratification delay has cost
nodes.fol: (forall (t e1 e2 a) (if (and (gratificationDelay t e1 e2 a)(etc)) (exists (y) (cost y t a))))
nodes.english: Much of the issue in the choice between short-term and long-term goals is that there is usually a cost to the delay

nodes.name: Example universal rule
nodes.fol: (forall (x) (if (p x)(q x)))
nodes.english: Suppose for example that we want a rule that says this universal implication

nodes.name: Reified implication version
nodes.fol: (forall (e1 x) (if (p' e1 x) (exists (e2)(and (q' e2 x)(imply e1 e2)))))
nodes.english: We can make the implication relation between the eventualities explicit and write

nodes.name: Mutual belief in implication
nodes.fol: (forall (e1 x) (if (p' e1 x) (exists (e2 e3) (and (q' e2 x)(imply' e3 e1 e2)(mb S e3)))))
nodes.english: Now we can reify the implication and treat it as an object of mutual belief by a particular set S of agents

nodes.name: Definition of goalTheme
nodes.fol: (forall (s t) (iff (goalTheme t s) (forall (a e) (if (and (member a s)(member e t)) (exists (e1) (and (instance e1 e)(goal e1 a)))))))
nodes.english: We can define a 'goal theme' as a relation between a set of agents and a set of goals from which we can conclude those agents have those goals. If t is a goal theme among the group s, then t is a set of eventuality types and the members of s are likely to have as goals instances of the eventuality types in set t

nodes.name: Goal themes based on mutual belief
nodes.fol: (forall (s t e a) (if (and (goalTheme t s)(member e t)(member a s)) (exists (e0 e1 e2) (and (mb s e0)(causallyInvolved' e0 e1 e2) (instance e1 e)(thrive' e2 a)))))
nodes.english: Agents have goals because they believe they will contribute ultimately to the goal of thriving. Thus, we can characterize goal themes in terms of mutual belief in causal knowledge

nodes.name: Goal theme axiom schema
nodes.fol: (forall (s t x e1 e y) (if (and (dset s x e1)(p' e1 x)(singleton t e)(q' e y)) (goalTheme t s)))
nodes.english: A belief that it is a goal theme of a group defined by property p that q be true would be expressed by axioms of this form

nodes.name: Definition of hedonists
nodes.fol: (forall (s) (iff (hedonists s) (exists (t) (and (goalTheme t s) (forall (e a) (if (and (member e t)(member a s)) (pleasurable e a)))))))
nodes.english: Following up on our discussion of pleasure and pain, we can define a hedonist (or a set of hedonists) as someone who chooses goals that are pleasurable experiences

node_types.variable: Frequently used variables (2+ axioms in chapter)
